0.text: Taking care of children during COVID-19 is hard. You are heroes of the COVID-19 response. Nobody is doing this perfectly, but take a moment now to praise yourself for getting this far.

66.text: Did you know that you are one of the first people to receive these parenting messages? We would love to get your feedback on how to improve them for you and other families.

223.text: These tips were developed with the WHO and UNICEF for YOU. They include advice on parenting and reducing stress, as well as lots of fun activities to do with your children.

367.text: Taking care of children can be difficult even in the best of times. COVID-19 has made it even more challenging.

387.text: Please tell us what is the most difficult situation you have recently encountered as a parent:

468.text: All children misbehave. It is normal when children are tired, hungry, afraid, or learning independence. One thing you can try is catching misbehavior early and distracting your kids’ attention to something positive. It actually works!

504.text: It is completely normal to feel stressed, afraid, angry, and depressed during this time. You are not alone. These tips will help you take care of yourself so you can take care of your children.

539.text: It is really hard to help our children continue learning when schools are closed or part-open. One thing that might be helpful is to try and set up a daily schedule that includes time for schoolwork and time for fun.

579.text: It can be difficult to know how to talk your children about COVID-19, especially since we are learning about it too.

601.text: The important thing is to be open and listen to your children. Be honest and supportive. Show them that you care.

622.text: Parenting is really hard. But there are things we can do to make things easier. We are here to help!

642.text: This is a stressful time for all of us. The more we listen to each other and show children how we keep ourselves healthy, the more they will feel secure and loved.

674.text: Millions are stressed about money because of COVID-19. Children or teenagers asking for things can cause arguments.  It can help them a lot when we involve them with family budgeting.

705.text: There are lots of risks to children online. But you can help protect your children by setting up easy tech fixes and creating health and safe online habits.

733.text: Spending even just a few minutes a day focused on having fun with your children can help your relationship. If you are really busy it could be tidying or cleaning together - just make it fun!

769.text: We spend a lot of time indoors with a young baby, and Covid-19 makes it much more intense.  It is completely normal to feel isolated, overwhelmed, anxious, and scared for you and your baby.

804.text: Congratulations! You have added your first parenting skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Each day you will learn a new skill so that you can be build a happy home for you and your family.

838.text: Here is a song that we made just for parents like you! Have a great day!

1351.text: Thanks so much for answering these questions! We really appreciate it.

1364.text: • Cover your face with your hands.

1371.text: • Quickly show your face and say "Peek-a-Boo!" or "Hello!" Babies love it!

1385.text: Look at your baby in the eyes and make different funny faces.

1398.text: Make a big face. Make a small face. Make a happy face. Make a surprised face.

1415.text: Which ones make your baby smile or laugh? Do them again, even bigger this time!

1430.text: Play with different feelings and add sounds.

1438.text: Copy their facial expressions too. Exaggerate them to make them funny.

1449.text: Always end on a positive expression!

1457.text: • Get to your baby's level so they can see you and hear you.

1472.text: • Copy their facial expressions and sounds.

1480.text: • It is so simple while creating a strong bond between you and your baby!

1499.text: Lie your baby on their back after washing them or changing their diaper

1512.text: Tell them the sun is coming! Wiggle your fingers like sunrays above their head and make your face a big smiling sun.

1534.text: Tell them the wind is coming! Blow softly over their body.

1545.text: Tell them the rain is coming! Use your fingers to gently pat over their whole body like light raindrops.

1564.text: Tell them the clouds are coming! Wrap the towel or cloth around them like a blanket and cuddle them

1584.text: Play with different weathers. Which one does your baby like best?

1595.text: Add sound effects or make it into a little song. Use the tune of another song you know!

1615.text: Find an empty, clean plastic bottle or pot with a lid that closes tight.

1629.text: Fill it with sand, stones, uncooked rice, beans or any small objects that make an interesting sound.

1647.text: Move your body as you shake it in front of your baby

1659.text: If it is safe, give it to your baby to shake!

1670.text: Get creative! Can you find something colourful or try it with water?

1683.text: What sounds does your baby like?

1691.text: Put your baby on their back

1697.text: Wiggle their toe and say, “This little toe goes [funny sound]”

1708.text: Make a funny sound for each toe

1715.text: Play with different sounds. For example, animal sounds, popping sounds, squeaky sounds, fart sounds.

1730.text: Repeat this for all ten toes.

1737.text: Try to make the last toe the biggest and funniest sound!

1752.text: Sit on a chair and put your toddler on your lap facing you. Hold them firmly under the arms.

1771.text: Gently bounce your legs and say in a soft voice “Baby horse, baby horse, baby horse, baby horse”

1789.text: Bounce your legs a bit more and say a bit louder “Little horse, little horse, little horse, little horse”

1808.text: Bounce your legs more and say louder “Big horse, big horse, big horse, big horse”

1823.text: When you call out “Down in a ditch!” open your knees and let your child drop down between them. Make sure you hold them so they don’t fall far!

1855.text: Put on your favourite music or sing your favourite song and dance around the room with your toddler. If you have a baby hold them while you dance.

1884.text: Dance in different ways or with different parts of your body

1895.text: For example, “Dance like a monkey”, “Dance like a chicken” or “Let’s dance with our knees and hips”

1913.text: Think up different instructions. Be seriously playful!

1921.text: When the music stops, everyone does a funny freeze

1930.text: Notice what rhythms or movement they like!

1938.text: When your baby or toddler cries, sing a soft song to calm you both down

1953.text: Sing a soothing song you know or make up your own with a simple melody and some soothing words

1972.text: Repeat it over and over in a rhythmical way. For example, “My little one, oh little one”

1989.text: Sing the same song regularly so your child gets used to it!
